item.text: [[Decentralised Consensus]]
[[Decentralised Infrastructure]]

Decentralisation is the process of redistributing or dispersing functions, powers, people or things away from a central location or authority. While centralisation, especially in the governmental sphere, is widely studied and practiced, there is no common definition or understanding of decentralisation. The meaning of decentralization may vary in part because of the different ways it is applied. Concepts of decentralisation have been applied to group dynamics and management science in private businesses and organisations, political science, law and public administration, economics and technology.

Decentralisation is the process of redistributing or dispersing functions, powers, people or things away from a central location or authority. Concepts of decentralisation have been applied to group dynamics and management science in private businesses and organisations, political science, law and public administration, economics and technology.
There is a distinction between decentralised and distributed structure:

There is a distinction between decentralised and distributed structure. Centralised, Decentralised, Distributed, Federated - are all ways to describe different network architectures. Read more on [http://networkcultures.org/unlikeus/resources/articles/what-is-a-federated-network/ Network Cultures]
It is important to keep in mind that these terms can be confusing - system can be decentralised to certain extent, or some processes can be decentralised while other are not.

In any system: whether it is technology or society - decentralised and distributed architecture is considered more resilient.
